meta.title: Housing Fit For Purpose: Performance, Feedback and Learning
meta.author: Fionn Stevenson

parts.title: Introduction to Housing Performance Evaluation
parts.body: Housing Performance Evaluation has evolved over the past century, starting from public health concerns in Victorian times when it was linked with sanitation and inhabitant health. Early laws aimed to prevent housing-related diseases, but lacked insights into actual performance. By the 19th century's end, reformers like Octavia Hill associated housing quality with occupant behavior, a link that persists today, connecting well-being and dwelling conditions. Post-WWII, modernism spurred interest in healthier design, but lacked comprehensive evaluation methods. It's crucial now to integrate feedback from inhabitants, reflecting their motivations and behaviors, to improve future designs.

parts.title: Evolution of Housing Evaluation and Building Performance Evaluation (BPE)
parts.body: Housing evaluation has evolved over time, influenced by energy crises and climate change. Initially, housing surveys in the UK were limited to structure and basic amenities, with little input from inhabitants. Progress was made with the inclusion of surveys like the English House Condition Survey in 1967 and later studies that evaluated more broadly, including environmental and behavioural aspects. However, earlier monitoring efforts and performance evaluations often lacked depth or integration with inhabitants' experiences, necessitating interdisciplinary collaboration between social sciences and building sciences to create more comprehensive evaluations. The introduction of building performance evaluation (BPE) aimed to close gaps between designed and actual performance by including occupant experience and environmental impact, such as energy use and emissions. Yet challenges persist due to institutional reluctance and regulatory limitations. Evolving concepts, such as the integration of social interaction with environmental dynamics and sustainability standards like Passivhaus, aim to drive improved housing performance. However, real-world applications of BPE are hampered by disparate regulations and inconsistent metrics across regions and disciplines, underlining the vital need for feedback loops that include detailed occupant input to address performance deviations.

parts.title: Socio-Cultural Factors in Housing Performance
parts.body: This section explores a range of socio-cultural factors that influence housing performance. These include needs, perceptions, behaviors, motivations, and how they can be effectively integrated into Building Performance Evaluations (BPE). Understanding socio-cultural aspects is crucial because homes, despite having the same design, can exhibit vastly different energy usages due to the inhabitants' behaviors. Theories from human geography, sociology, and psychology, among others, provide insights into these interactions. The history and culture of the home and its inhabitants are significant influences and should be factored into BPE. Moreover, integrating insights from multiple disciplines, such as engineering and social sciences, leads to a more comprehensive understanding of housing performance.

parts.title: Longitudinal Study for Housing Adaptation
parts.body: The text discusses how a home's life cycle is influenced by inhabitant changes and the physical wear of materials. Stewart Brand’s diagram outlines these life cycles, highlighting the timeframe for components such as structure and services. Housing BPE (Building Performance Evaluation) can provide insights into a home's adaptability over time. Longitudinal studies are particularly useful for understanding changes in technologies and how homes adapt to shifts in living practices. This practice helps in identifying the direct link between the initial costs and maintenance expenses. A practical case study at Kincardine O’Neil showed failed enforcement of thermal issues despite tenant satisfaction. Longitudinal studies like this allow for examining ongoing maintenance and technological impacts, which reveal gaps in communication between tenants and housing managers. The second study indicated significant knowledge gaps in tenants regarding energy-saving technologies, like MVHR systems. These evaluations underscore the lack of guidance provided to tenants and how it impacts long-term housing sustainability.

parts.title: Longitudinal BPE Learning and Feedback Cycles
parts.body: Longitudinal BPE helps organisations learn over time, creating benchmarks for evaluating changes in homes and tech. This fosters insight into information management, tech innovation, and inhabitant engagement. It also preserves tacit knowledge even when staff leave, making organisations more resilient. Learning is transforming direct experiences into ideas and testing them to gain new insights. Organisational learning, as seen in BPE, involves individuals gaining knowledge and sharing it at a group level, establishing new routines. BPE lessons from design to inhabitation stages can be integrated back into projects or stored for future use. This builds a knowledge base for decision-making. Levels 4 and 5 in learning involve knowledge management and practice, which embed lessons throughout organisations. The feedback cycle continuously enhances housing projects.

parts.title: International BPE and Standards
parts.body: International BPE Standards: Different international building performance standards exist, each shaped by local histories, cultures, and environments. Voluntary international protocols, like the International Performance Measurement and Verification Protocol (IPMVP), often focus only on energy and water usage. However, standards such as LEED and BREEAM focus on broader areas like health, transport and water, aiming at sustainable certifications. These standards usually promote predictive evaluation but are moving towards measuring performance. Newbuild and Retrofit Case Studies: Chapter 10 introduces international case studies of Building Performance Evaluation (BPE), highlighting differences in international standards. It shows how newbuild projects have dominated BPE studies, overshadowing the importance of retrofit projects. Retrofitting is crucial as it significantly impacts carbon emissions reduction, yet BPE in retrofits remains underexplored. This chapter also covers international knowledge exchange in BPE and compares methodologies and techniques used globally.

parts.title: International Knowledge Exchange and BPE Methods
parts.body:
International Knowledge Exchange and BPE Methods

International Knowledge Exchange has been successful through Passivhaus, where its performance has been assessed globally, but mainly as proof rather than for design improvements. Cross-cultural challenges highlight that what's effective in one country may not be in another. An EU-funded project, BuPESA, exchanged BPE knowledge between England and Poland, overcoming differences in carbon emission priorities. International BPE experiences from Brazil and Australia show diverse applications. In Brazil, using action research with co-production methods uncovered acoustic and design issues in a social housing project, leading to inhabitants making self-build adaptations. In Australia, a BPE study on award-winning homes revealed that people were comfortable with adaptive comfort measures even if homes didn't meet regulatory temperature ranges, prompting recommendations to consider inhabitants’ practices in building standards.

parts.title: The Ethics of Feedback in BPE
parts.body: The chapter discusses the ethics involved in Building Performance Evaluation (BPE), highlighting the intrusive nature of such studies into privacy and how ethical considerations must be handled to respect participants' rights. Housing BPE can impact personal, physical, and organisational data, necessitating clear policies on data ownership, use, and consent. Ethical guidelines recommend honesty, integrity, and confidentiality, and emphasise avoiding harm to both inhabitants and the physical home. This includes careful management of any potential disturbance from monitoring equipment.

parts.title: Effective Housing Feedback and BPE Integration
parts.body: Good housing improves through feedback from use, informing future design and delivery. Feedback enhances built practices by refining solutions, helping professionals identify effective aspects of their work. In architecture, feedback culture needs development despite strong ties in medical fields between practice, education, and research. Effective feedback loops in BPE depend on combining tacit knowledge, negotiation skills, and recognizing when to seek others’ input, improving housing performance understanding. Willingness to act on feedback without fear of blame leads to a no-blame learning process, embedding feedback from the start, ensuring improvement throughout the project lifecycle. This segment outlines the importance of integrating Building Performance Evaluation (BPE) within processes to enhance practice for clients and design teams. Building feedback into the project lifecycle using a six-step cyclical model connects stages from initial planning to handover, adapting practices by examining previous feedback. The framework involves setting key aims, engaging clients, assessing resource needs, and embedding BPE in design reviews and commissioning stages, working collaboratively with inhabitants. This comprehensive approach seeks continuous improvement by treating BPE as a strategic part of the housing project from the onset, aiming for inclusive, accurate project comprehension and effective development.

parts.title: Ensuring Impactful BPE Insights
parts.body: To achieve maximum impact with Building Performance Evaluation (BPE), it is important for both project and organizational learning. This includes immediate and strategic actions based on study results. Analysis should focus on comparing results with design intentions regarding energy, CO2 emissions, and indoor environment quality. Benchmark against sustainable design standards and align with practice/client KPIs to help improve home performance. Identifying why things work or present challenges can lead to uncovering issues and establishing best practices. Cross-checking findings from both physical construction and social surveys is crucial to reveal discrepancies and establish baselines for evaluation.
